Arkansas: The Arkansas Youth Hiring Act was signed by Governor Huckabee Sanders in March 2023. It withdraws the requirement for work permits for minors.
Georgia: In 2023 a bill was introduced to withdraw the requirement for work permits and age certificates in Georgia. The bill was withdrawn.
Indiana: In 2021, Indiana ended the requirement for work permits for minors and replaced it with an employer registration system for any employer hiring 5 or more minors.
Iowa: Amendments to Iowa's child labor laws were signed by Governor Reynolds in May 2023. Children can now work in some hazardous occupations from the age of 14, and 14-15 year olds can work 6 hours per day during the school week (among other changes). Children under 14 are now prohibited from doing any type of work.
Maine: In early 2023 two amendments on the employment of minors were introduced: a subminimum wage for minors, and an increase in hours worked per week by a minor who is home-schooled.
Michigan: In 2022 Michigan passed laws to enable minors to sell and serve alcohol.
Minnesota: In Minnesota two bills are in progress: one will lower the minimum age for hazardous work (construction and building sites) to 16, the other will allow 14-15 year olds to start work at 6.30 AM, and end work at 11 PM during vacations and Fri-Sat when school is in session.
Missouri: In Missouri two bills are in progress: one will withdraw the requirement for work permits, and the other will add a 10 PM curfew for 16-17 year olds Sun-Thurs when school is in session.
Nebraska: At present, minors receive the Nebraskan minimum wage ($10.50 in 2023 rising to $15 by 2026). In January 2023, a bill was introduced to create a subminimum wage for minors of $9 in 2023, rising to $10 by 2026.
New Hampshire: In 2022 New Hampshire enacted new laws which increased the hours 16-17 year olds who are full-time students can work when school is in session from 30 to 35; it also reduced the age at which a minor can bus tables where alcohol is served and restock alcohol products to 14, with adult supervision.
New Jersey: In 2022, Governor Murphy signed amendments to New Jersey's child labor laws. 16-17 year olds can now work 50 hours per week all year instead of 40, and 14-15 year olds can work 8 hours a day and 40 hours per week in vacations. Parental and school authority was also withdrawn from the work permit process.
Ohio: In May 2023, the Ohio Senate passed a bill to allow 14-15 year olds to work up to 9 PM on school nights. Governor DeWine has yet to sign the bill into law.
South Dakota: In 2023, a bill was introduced in South Dakota to allow children under the age of 14 to work up to 9 PM throughout the year. This was withdrawn. Children under the age of 14 can currently work until 7 PM.
Tennessee: In 2023, Tennessee changed its child labor laws to allow 16-17 year olds to work in venues where more than 25% of revenue comes from alcohol.
Virginia: In 2023 a bill was introduced in Virginia to create a subminimum wage for minors. The bill failed in the House.
Wisconsin: In 2022, Governor Evers vetoed a bill which would have allowed 14-15 year olds to start work at 6 AM and end at 9.30 PM Sun-Thurs, and end at 11 PM during vacations and on Fri-Sat, on the condition that the employer did not fall under the FLSA. In 2023, a bill was introduced to allow 14 year olds to carry alcohol to customers in bars/restaurants.

Alaska: No minimum age: minors under 14 years can work casing cans in canneries under supervision.
South Dakota: No miminum age (with limitations on type and lateness of work for children under 14)

Arizona: 16 year olds are permitted to drive; 16-17 year olds can undertake hazardous work if employed by a family member
DC: 16 year olds can work with and clean power-driven machinery
Florida: 16 year olds are permitted to drive

State: Working hours when school is in session (14-15 year olds)

Alaska: 9 hours which should include school and work per day
Mississippi: 8 hours if enrolled in school and the work is in a mill, cannery, workshop, factory, or manufacturing establishment

Michigan: 48 hours if the 14-15 year old is not in school
Mississippi: 44 hours if enrolled in school and the work is in a mill, cannery, workshop, factory, or manufacturing establishment
Wisconsin: 24 hours if school is in session for fewer than 5 days

State: Working time (start at 7 AM end at 7 PM)
Arkansas:
Start at 6 AM
Fri-Sat: start at 6 AM and end at 9 PM
Alaska: Start at 5 AM and end at 9 PM
Arizona:
Start at 6 AM and end at 9:30 PM
Fri-Sat: start at 6 AM and end at 11 PM
Colorado:
Start at 5 AM
and end at 9:30 PM
Fri-Sat: can end after 9.30 PM
Georgia: Start at 6 AM and end at 9 PM
Mississippi: Start 6 AM if enrolled in school and the work is in a mill, cannery, workshop, factory, or manufacturing establishment
Nebraska: Start at 6 AM and end at 10 PM
South Dakota:
End at 10 PM
Fri-Sat: can work later than 10 PM
Tennessee:
Fri-Sat: end at 9 PM
Sat-Sun: start at 6 PM
Texas:
Start at 5 AM and end at 10 PM
Fri-Sat: end at midnight
Utah:
Start at 5 AM and end at 9.30 PM
Fri-Sat: can end after 9.30 PM
Sat-Sun: can start before 5 AM

State: Working hours June 1st - Labor Day Weekend (14-15 year olds)

Mississippi: 44 hours if enrolled in school and the work is in a mill, cannery, workshop, factory, or manufacturing establishment

State: Working time (start at 7 AM end at 9 PM)
Arizona: Start at 6 AM and end at 11 PM
Colorado: Start at 5 AM and can work after 9.30 PM
Mississippi: Start 6 AM if enrolled in school and the work is in a mill, cannery, workshop, factory, or manufacturing establishment
Nebraska: Start at 6 AM and end at 10 PM
Texas: Start at 5 AM and end at midnight
Utah: Can start before 5 AM and end after 9.30 PM

State: Limit no. days/week a minor can work?

Mississippi: Yes if the work is in a mill, cannery, workshop, factory, or manufacturing establishment

Kansas: Yes (only for children not in school)

Michigan: Yes (24 hours per week if in school when school is in session; start at 6 AM and end at 10.30 PM Sun-Thurs when school is in session; end at 11.30 PM Fri-Sat when school is in session; end 11.30pm during vacations)
